Award.AwardTitle: CCSS: Collaborative Research: Learn-and-Adapt to Manage Dynamic Cyber-Physical Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates algorithmic innovations targeting the cyber-physical system (CPS) opportunities emerging from cloud, transportation, and power networks. The envisioned advances pertain to models and algorithms for learn-and-adapt approaches to managing CPS; online data-driven workload balancing for sustainable data center networks; real-time traffic management for transportation networks in smart cities; and learning-aided online decentralized energy management for smart power networks.

The proposed research has great potential for social, environmental, and economic benefits, as it directly impacts the wireless Internet, scalable cloud networks, intelligent transportation, and microgrids supporting smart homes and cars. Cloud users' experience can be enhanced with markedly low request delay. Smart cars can end up consuming less fuel, and experience less waiting time at road intersections due to efficient signal control and vehicle routing. Finally, power grid operators can benefit from relaxed battery capacity requirements and fast electric vehicle charging at substations. Broader transformative impact will be effected by reaching out to middle-school students and the community, involving undergraduates in research, increasing participation of under-represented minorities, and promoting a scientifically literate public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching objective of this research project has been to integrate data analytics into system management policies to permeate benefits of machine learning into cyber-physical system (CPS) designs. A comprehensive framework is put forth  based on state-of-the-art optimization and statistical inference tools to perform online distributed operations while accounting for the dynamics of CPS designs. Innovative models and algorithms were developed; their performance was quantitatively assessed; and their merits were demonstrated in the context of cloud, communications, and power networks for the smart grid. Sustainable data center networks can benefit from data-driven load balancing approaches. Ttransportation networks in smart cities can learn-and-adapt real-time traffic; and smart power networks can utilize the novel tools for monitoring, prevention of blackouts, and optimization of their efficiency. 

The research component was also integrated with an educational component. Half a dozen PhDs were supported and the graduates are now faculty members (RPI, UC Irvine, Beijing Inst. of Technology), and researchers in the data science Industry (Samsung, Google and Amazon).  Monthly reading group meetings were organized on advances related to network science, online convex optimization and machine learning for big data analytics with applications to sensing and resource allocation for communication, social, brain, and power networks with renewables and electric vehicles. Knowledge was disseminated through dozens of tutorials, keynote, plenary and cooloquia presentations, journal and conference papers in flagship venues and international conferences, patents, half a dozen book chapters, and a research monograph. The research was recognized through three best paper awards (1 journal and 2 conferences), and the PI received additional prestigious awards over the course of the project. Those include the IEEE-SPS "Norbert Wiener" Society Award (2019); EURASIP's "A. Papoulis" Society Award (2020); the IEEE ComSocEducation Award (2019); foreign membership of the AcademiaEuropaea (2020), and fellowships of the US National Academy of Inventors (2019); and the European Academy of Sciences (2020).
